Description: Small mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back with prothorax and elytra indicated by single lines, and small triangles marking winglets on either side behind the prothorax line; at side, legs just marked by two horizontal lines; underside deeply incised with schematic representation of a lion attacking an ibex from behind; longitudinally pierced; hard, yellowish green glaze surviving on device; hard and yellowish core; chipped surface on back.
Curator's comments: This scarab, produced in the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming), belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, especially found in Carthage, Cumae and Perachora (Gorton 1996, 114-117, type XXXII, subtype A2-27a, see especially A3 for this piece). A second scarab, manufactured in Egyptian blue and also discovered in Naukratis, presents a similar scene (Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, no. 6). Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 115, Type XXXII A3)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.031) (phase 3)
Condition: Fair, glaze slightly damaged on back of scarab
